body: LGTM and Jenkins is happy.
Np. No urgency. This is not a bug, just a long delayed improvement.

R: @davorbonaci context.
R: -@dhalperi travel coming soon.

One issue I found is that gcs writes could be buffered in the client, and the exception could be deferred until the file is closed. The result is one exception per bundle in TextIO.Write and BigQueryIO.Write.

I have verified following cases with DirectRunner:
(There is no public folder in gcp, so only one test case for Write.)
1. TextIO.Read from public gcp input files works.
2. TextIO.Read from private gcp input files failed with expected exception.
3. BigQueryIO.Read from public/private dataset failed. Looks to me, BigQuery required authenticated users. Exceptions are expected. 
4.TextIO.Write (and, BigQuery.Write which write to gcs) failed. There is one exception for each write bundle. The exception itself is expected.

LGTM, but the boolean `UsesProvidedSparkContext` doesn't link directly to Spark dependencies and moving it means that we can no longer create a `PipelineOptions` with `UsesProvidedSparkContext` using command-line arguments which can be very useful sometimes.

@amitsela That's what we should have done (setting the flag if the context was set programmatically), but unfortunately I didn't think about it at the time. And from what we saw, concerning the `ProvidedSparkContext`, people tend to create a SparkPipelineOptions using command-line arguments with `UsesProvidedSparkContext` set to `true` and then inject the SparkContext using `SetProvidedSparkContext` programmatically at the last moment.

We can totally look at setting `UsesProvidedSparkContext` to true once the `SetProvidedSparkContext` is used.

The way I see it, we have two ways to solve this:
1. Remove the `UsesProvidedSparkContext` option, and have it implicitly "set" by  checking `ProvidedSparkContext != null`.
2. Moving `UsesProvidedSparkContext` to `SparkPipelineOptions`, and letting users provide command-line flag (for example) to toggle a driver code that will set (and start!) a provided context.

I guess (2) is reasonable.

Thoughts ?
2 LGTM
Rebased, AutoValue use, etc. Not fully ready for review anyway.

I kept registerStandardIOFactories backward compatible. We can remove it once worker code is updated.

Regarding the test and the thread created for the publisher in `testRead()` test, I took a thread dump.
I can see a thread waiting on `message = queue.poll(5, TimeUnit.SECONDS);` as expected. However, I don't see the publisher method and the direct runner is blocked there:

```
"main@1" prio=5 tid=0x1 nid=NA waiting
  java.lang.Thread.State: WAITING
      at sun.misc.Unsafe.park(Unsafe.java:-1)
      at java.util.concurrent.locks.LockSupport.parkNanos(LockSupport.java:215)
      at java.util.concurrent.locks.AbstractQueuedSynchronizer$ConditionObject.awaitNanos(AbstractQueuedSynchronizer.java:2078)
      at java.util.concurrent.ArrayBlockingQueue.poll(ArrayBlockingQueue.java:418)
      at org.apache.beam.runners.direct.ExecutorServiceParallelExecutor.awaitCompletion(ExecutorServiceParallelExecutor.java:240)
      at org.apache.beam.runners.direct.DirectRunner$DirectPipelineResult.waitUntilFinish(DirectRunner.java:444)
      at org.apache.beam.runners.direct.DirectRunner.run(DirectRunner.java:350)
      at org.apache.beam.runners.direct.DirectRunner.run(DirectRunner.java:75)
      at org.apache.beam.sdk.Pipeline.run(Pipeline.java:182)
      at org.apache.beam.sdk.testing.TestPipeline.run(TestPipeline.java:112)
      at org.apache.beam.sdk.io.mqtt.MqttIOTest.testRead(MqttIOTest.java:119)
```

so on `pipeline.run()`. Even if I move `pipeline.run()` before the publisher client, the behavior is the same.

As the pipeline is waiting for the message, that's why I created another thread to publish in the MQTT topic while the pipeline is consuming (in the same time) from the topic.

I don't see how to avoid this publisher thread as the direct runner is blocking.

CC: @davorbonaci

I have concerns about this pull request.
- It seems to establish a pattern that `@BeforeClass` is needed across all tests. This looks like several lines of unnecessary boilerplate. Can we find a pattern that avoids this?
- It solves the problem by somewhat decreasing the utility offered of the test. Before you could set an input to anything and corresponding checksum -- the test would work. This utility has been removed.

Can we fix up this pull request or, alternatively, explain in this pull request why this is a good change.

Thanks!
PTAL
R: @davorbonaci since Dan is busy.
Failed in DataflowRunner without an error message being returned; got past the initial options breakage that this PR addresses. We'll see if it is repeatable.

Re: "It solves the problem by somewhat decreasing the utility offered of the test."
I think the previous utility comes from the improperly uses of PipelineOptions:
1. It was using PipelineOptions as the parser for arguments only used in IT tests main(), such as checksum (which is not a true pipeline option).
2. It is still using PipelineOptions as the arguments parser for WordCount.main(). All cmd arguments, relevant or irrelevant, are passed to WordCount.
WordCount.main(TestPipeline.convertToArgs(options))

Those improper uses requires declaring all PipelineOptions in the global namespace through register(), which caused the post-submit failure.

This PR removed the first improper use, and reduced some utilities (which we are not currently depends on). So, I think it is a good change.

There is some ideas about support a testArg for ITs tests in here:
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-898?focusedCommentId=15648972&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-15648972

This PR makes the behavior same across pre and post commit. I don't understand how the tox caching actually works but unless post submit execution times significantly increase, this is a clean option.

via a completely unscientific sampling,

3 builds after cache deleted: 6:30, 5:43, 6:03

3 successful builds before cache deleted: 7:57, 6:40, 6:56

Doesn't look like it's a lot if it did change at all.

R: @jkff
R: @robertwb

Avro learns the schema from the class definition through reflection. This is convenient for simple classes like this.

E.g. we could add a 'timestamp' field to KafkaCheckpointMark class, and Avro would be still be able to read old checkpoint mark that didn't have timestamp (it would leave it at default or null value).
@markflyhigh can you rebase to kick the tests until we get a clean execution? (or until you uncover a real bug)
Jenkins failure is [BEAM-747](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-747). The fact that the pipeline executed at all indicates that these changes did not break the worker.

LGTM. Merging.

LGTM. Merging. Thanks @jbonofre.
+R @aaltay

> And so final is not allowed anymore ?

Yep, Avro requires no-arg constructor that it uses while creating a new object from serialized bytes. Thats why I could not use TopicPartition class from Kafka directly.
R: @davorbonaci / @francesperry
Caveat: it is a bit of a copy/paste/modify job. The deps from the other archetype satisfied the gaming example, which means they need to be pruned.

Hi Andrew, in general we work very hard to ensure that our API surface is clean, and limited to only code we intend to document and support for years. Private internal utility functions should stay internal -- but I think there's no harm in copying the 10 lines of code where you need them.

Hi @dhalperi, thanks for the quick response. So there was a conscious choice to change it to private? It used to be public and it is still documented on the class: https://github.com/andrewsmartin/incubator-beam/blob/2ba3ab20363a6160d3bf42b8c321fc299babfcef/sdks/java/io/google-cloud-platform/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/io/gcp/bigquery/BigQueryIO.java#L151
